reviewerName: Chris McLeod ""Never have I been a blue c...
reviewText: You cannot review this DVD without watching it from start to finish.Heart masterfully goes from start to finish playing live every song on their debut album "Dreamboat Annie." With a legendary album like "Dreamboat Annie," it's sometimes easy to forget just how magnificent each song really was. Gigantic rock bands like Heart are remembered by their hits, and there were certainly hits on Dreamboat Annie (Crazy on You, Magic Man). But what's often forgetten are the true masterpieces in the middle. Such as "Soul of the Soul," "Sing Child," and the 3 "Dreamboat Annie's."Not only do they play the entire album, the encore features some powerhouse covers and classics like "Mistral Wind" from Heart's "Dog and Butterfly" album, as well as Led Zeppelin's "Black Dog."Heart has not lost any of their touch. Nancy's raw and pure guitar playing exudes emotion, while the unmistakable powerhouse vocals of Ann Wilson, to this day, can give one chills.This DVD release is why I love music. It takes you through a roller coaster ride of memories and emotions. Some of my own, and some of theirs. In some moments you just want to grab an instrument and rock with them, while others you cannot do anything but sit in awe and their pure magnificence.True legends..don't miss this one folks, it's a keeper.
summary: Heading out this morning, into the sun...

reviewText: Recording a live concert is like trying to capture lightening in a bottle: unless everything is absolutely perfect it misses the delicate interweaving between performer and audience.  In my opinion, the single finest live recording made is Judy Garland At Carnegie Hall; likewise, the single finest live filmed concert is Kate Bush Live At the Hammersmith Odeon.  Such standards are very high, and its forgiveable that most others don't quite reach them.  Queen, Pink Floyd, Fleetwood Mac, Rush, Led Zeppelin never quite reached it.  Neither does Heart.Heart began in 1967 as an all-male band in Canada, having some success on the Vancouver club scene but never really taking off until about 1974, when Anne and Nancy Wilson, two sisters from Seattle, joined the line up.  Suddenly the dynamics of the band changed: Heart was now about the two women, Anne with extraordinary vocals and Nancy with one hell of a guitar. There had been female hard rockers in the past--certainly Janis Joplin and Grace Slick qualify--but none that had really "fronted" a band.  Heart was unusual, unexpected, and when they recorded DREAMBOAT ANNIE in 1975 it was a smash and generated three major single hits.  With success, however, came dissention, and after several albums and romantic relationships that turned combative one thing became clear: for all practical intents and purposes, Heart WAS Anne and Nancy Wilson, and the remaining line up were expert sidemen, nothing more.Like every band, Heart has had its ups and downs, and over the years the band went from being a stadium act to a club act and at present does extremely well in theatres and auditoriums where a loyal fan base and their hard rocking sound keeps them on a heavy tour schedule.  Among the audience favorites are "Magic Man," "Crazy On You," "Dreamboat Annie," and "Sing, Child, Sing"--all songs from DREAMBOAT ANNIE.  In 2007 the Wilson sisters, with a new backing line up, performed the whole of the album at the Orpheum Theatre in Los Angeles, and this DVD is the result.  And it is a good DVD, beginning with a short series of interviews that document the band's rise, continuing with the album, taking a brief break for another interview, and then finishing with a series of encores that demonstrate why Heart is one of the few bands than can cover Led Zeppelin with credibility.  It's all good stuff.But, as I said at the beginning, trying to record or film a live concert is like trying to capture lightening in a bottle.  We know they're good, but the sound and the camera simply can't take it all in.  Heart is frequently described as a band that is best heard live, and there is some truth to that--I saw them perform about two years ago and they simply blow you away--and with any luck somebody will do a concert film that does them justice.  But while this one is good, it isn't quite the one you really want.GFT, Amazon Reviewer

reviewText: Heart's April 2007 stage performance of their 1976 debut LP has been issued as both a CD and this DVD. Please check the CD listing (Dreamboat Annie Live) for a review of the musical content.The DVD edition includes the full contents of the CD: a start-to-finish run-through of the "Dreamboat Annie" LP, plus encore covers of Led Zeppelin, The Who and Pink Floyd, and Heart's ode to "Stairway to Heaven," "Mistral Wind." In addition, the DVD opens with a contemporary interview of Ann and Nancy Wilson in which they discuss the band's early days, an interview with the original LP producer, Mike Flicker, and a montage of vintage photos. The encores are introduced by additional interview footage in which the Wilson sisters discuss their early influences. All in all, there's 82 minutes of performance and interview footage.Both the interviews and concert are shot in wide-screen, and the audio is available in both stereo and 5.1 surround. Recorded in front of a hand-picked audience of Heart fan club members, the band is charged up (Nancy Wilson proves herself to be an especially animated guitarist), and the intercut shots of the crowd add to the overall excitement. A few members of the audience turn up on a bonus feature, "Heart Mongers Speak," in which they're interviewed post-concert. A low resolution photo gallery is also provided on disc.The DVD is a nice bonus for Heart completists, but with the band letting the album itself take center stage, the visual element isn't essential to enjoying this nostalgic run-through of this classic LP. [2007 hyperbolium dot com]
summary: Video document of 2007 live LP performance

reviewText: The Heart sisters can still nail you to the floor with their performance.Highlights for me were "Soul of the Sea", "Sing Child", and "How Deep it Goes". But I got to say that Heart's cover of The Who's "Love Reign O're Me" is one of the most powerful performance pieces I have ever seen.What song can't she sing?I agree with the other reviewer who complained about the mixing of the surround sound.What you might try is changing your amp settings by boosting the center channel and reducing the back channels.This seemed to reduce the boominess and brought out Ann's vocals from the the mix.Worked good for me.This is too good a concert to let slip by.It is definitely a different feel than the Live Seatle concert from a couple of years ago.
summary: Still one of the greatest rock acts around today
Title: N/A

reviewText: I had high expectations for this live DVD, but it was an utter disappointment.  It started off with interviews that went too long.  When the performances started with "Magic Man", it was immediately apparent that something was wrong.  They sounded like a band that had never played together before, and even the Wilson sisters sounded like they had not rehearsed in forever and a day.  Ann's singing wasn't off-key, but the notes that she was singing, in the correct key, were not the correct notes.  It is not unusual for a natural singer to be able to ad lib in the correct key, but not singing the correct notes, and this is exactly what she was doing.  Nancy struggled so badly with the guitar intro to "Dreamboat Annie" that she grimaced, stopped and started over.  It was clear from the expression on her face that she was really struggling, and it suggested to me that she had not even picked up a guitar in quite a long while.  As I watched the closeups of her guitar work through the rest of the concert, it was continually apparent to me that she had not picked up a guitar in a long time.There is also a very obvious technical problem with the video.  It looked to me as though the even and odd frames had been assembled incorrectly duing the production of the DVD.  I have a brand new Sony TV, which has their latest and greatest reverse 3:2 pulldown technology, and I have not encountered this problem with any other DVD, so I must conclude that it was shot either with film cameras or with older video cameras that output only an analog video signal, and the assembly of the original frames into MPEG frames was simply done incorrectly.  The effect is quite awful, so bad in fact that it is difficult to watch.I eventually resorted to fast-forwarding to get through it.  Between the lackluster, unrehearsed performances and the messed-up video conversion, I just couldn't stand it.  I have several dozen music DVDs, and several of them are produced from classic performances from the early '70s, that someone discovered back on some dusty shelf.  In such cases, you accept the poor quality of the video, and you appreciate seeing a classic performance by one of your favorite bands captured in a live performance during their prime.  This is not a classic performance of Heart in their prime, and the people responsible for the video production, whose names are actually on the jacket case, are presumably the sort who think themselves artists of some sort, but who do not have adequate technical know-how.  The only musicians in this performance who seemed to have practiced at all, are the backup musicians.The bottom line is that this DVD is just a mess.  If you are a fan of Heart from the days of their prime, it is not likely that you will like this DVD.  The only sort of person that is likely to like this at all, would be someone who likes anything and everything by Heart, no matter what.

reviewText: If you like the original album of the same title you'll like this. Since a lot of the songs on this album were acoustic there is sort of an "unplugged" feel about this concert and the covers are great as usual. This album is easily equal to "Live in Seattle". It is interesting to hear the band perform songs they had written before they were famous and still do so with the same enthusiasm.Don't let any of these pseudo-intellectual critics fool you. This is Heart before MTV and it is a pleasure. There is nothing wrong with these performances - in fact they are almost note for note like the record. This was clearly a good idea and one worth preserving.
summary: For Fans Of The Album Only

reviewText: In 2007 I was honored with prize tickets to be a part of this wonderful night.  I entered an essay in a contest which focused on Heart's impact on the writers.  My readers know I am an avid rock apostle so this was great fun.The ladies were in fine form and the night was magical.  This was shown on DirecTV 101 and VH1 Classic, but there were some cuts to the broadcast.  This was to be one of the first, recording the performance of and entire album in correct sequence.  Because this was so personal for me, I'll just say fans of Heart over the years will love this, your young rocker girls should watch and learn and if you never were a fan, this will convert you to one.Metaldiva Sez:  This is a great addition to your collection of rock.  You can see me at about 8:44 and 14 minutes in.. I am the one that looks very much like our beloved Ann! Special and one hundred percent enjoyable.

reviewText: Dreamboat Annie Live captures Heart replicating the songs off their debut album 30 years later at the Orpheum Theatre in Los Angeles, CA.  Down to the Moog synthesizer on the opening track, "Magic Man," to the beautiful strings on "Soul of the Sea" by the Stockholm Strings, the Wilson sisters, Ann and Nancy, take viewers and concert goers down memory lane.  However, this live 2007 rendition of the classic album sounds as fresh as the original recording.From the soft ballads to the rock driven tracks, these women can rock.  For anyone who has seen Heart live, they are indeed a tight musical outfit.  Despite several line-up changes, the core of the band has always been Ann and Nancy, but Ben Smith and Ric Markmann provide the rhythm section, Craig Bartok excels with his raunchy guitar solos, and the keyboards are manned by Darian Sahanajan and Debbie Shair.  Ann's vocals are remarkable on all the tracks, and at times, especially during the bonus tracks to the Led Zeppelin covers, "Black Dog" and "Misty Mountain Hop," it sounds like she has channeled Robert Plant into her rock and roll soul; Heart's Zeppelin-like "Mistral Wind" is one of their most powerful songs, which Ann and Nancy perform with intensity and finesse.  Nancy Wilson also deserves praise for her backing vocals, rhythm, and her trademark solo acoustic guitar intro to the classic, "Crazy On You" and blues harp solo on "Sing Child."Besides the fabulous live concert, the interview of Ann and Nancy were insightful.  They shared their musical inspirations and influences to the making of the original studio recording, and if one listens carefully,  there is a little bit of Elton John, Pink Floyd, Beatles, and Led Zeppelin influence, which can be heard within the melodies and musical arrangements to the tracks on Dreamboat Annie.Overall, the Dreamboat Annie Live dvd is a must for any Heart fan.  And for ultimate listening and viewing pleasure, the volume should be turned up.
summary: A Reeling and a Rocking with Heart
Title: N/A

reviewText: This is the latest version of the Heart, which means only Anne and Nancy Wilson are left from the original band. Anne and Nancy Wilson turn in really good performances with a few inspired moments. The rest of the band are very good and turn in a better than workman-like performance, but the chemistry is different from the original band that made the original album.Maybe they should have taken this occasion to reunite the orignal band for a special one off show. I hope if Heart gets inducted in the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame the Wilson sisters remember the original guys. That's not to say that this isn't a good DVD because it is. But it is far from the definitive live performance of these songs, although it is very enjoyable and generally better than their last DVD.

reviewText: The DVD of DREAMBOAT ANNIE LIVE is a great video of Heart's live rendition of their classic 1976 debut album, which was a unique blend of Led Zeppelin, Southern rock, and Celtic folk-rock. It's especially interesting to note that after the song "White Lightning And Wine", lead singer Ann Wilson tells the audience not to mix the two. If actress Michelle Rodriguez had heard Wilson's warning before driving, she wouldn't currently be serving 180 days in an overcrowded, filthy jail. She should have been required to buy both the album and this DVD, which both contain this warning, as part of her probation, because she'd have learned something from it, as could Paris Hilton. This disclaimer at the end of the song inspired me to request ginger ale instead of wine to toast my grandfather on his 95th birthday, and my grandparents on their 75th anniversary. This DVD- and the accompanying CD- are a must-own for any Heart fan.
summary: Great Live DVD Performance Of A Classic Album
Title: N/A

reviewText: Heart's debut album is still my favorite of all their recordings, and this concert of the album being performed in it's entirety is pure magic from start to finish. Dreamboat Annie was always their most psychedelic and their most organic feeling album. Now Heart bring these wonderful, poetic songs to life again and also showcase how far they've came as musicians by enhancing on their own brand of rock they first created 30 years ago, especialy on "Sing Child," which one might call this concert's highlight as the violin section they included gives this updated live version a Dave Matthews Band kind of groove and leading into Ann Wilson's amazing flute solo very reminiscent of Jethro Tull. One might also call the highlight of this show taking place during the encore instead, in which Heart pay tribute to Pink Floyd, Led Zeppelin, and The Who, and they play these cover versions of their influences with such craft and passion that they make these classic tunes feel like their own. You don't even necessarily have to be a big Heart fan to enjoy this show. Quite simply, if you're a lover of classic rock in general, then you will love this concert.
Title: N/A

reviewText: As far as the performance goes, I much prefer either the Heart Alive in Seattle or Soundstage performance. The audio quality is better on those also. As for the video quality on this, what your picture looks like apparently will depend on your DVD player. There is a flaw in the frame conversion to video, as noted elsewhere here. It appears as minute, but very noticeable, horizontal black lines on edges in areas of movement. It does not appear in the interview portions, only the concert footage, and after the interlude interview, the video miraculously clears up for the "encore" portion of the concert. Somebody really poked the wrong button, or something. Two of my DVD players pass this flaw, while a Toshiba does a pretty good job of getting through it. It's not just a disc problem, or just a player problem, but rather how well your player can handle a flawed video conversion. Hence, some people do not report this, while others have.The audio on this DVD is pretty lackluster and inconsistent also. At track 9, the audio just falls flat and thin, with no bass at all, and drops to about half volume. Then it pumps back up for the next track. Pretty poor. Unless you want this for the Dreamboat Annie aspect, either Soundstage or Alive in Seattle is the far the better bet than this, both in performance and audio/video quality.
Title: N/A
